data.title: A question about the Cuman-Kipchak Confederation
data.meta_description: So I had a brief question is there an estimate of the total population in the Cuman-Kipchak Confederation?
data.text:
Not really since the extent of the confederation is unknown and heavily debated. Early Medieval Central Asian Population Estimates**»**Brill Online

Offers free 14 day trial to a reasonable paper talking about estimates.

Otherwise, the best advice is probably population density was something between 1-2 per square mile of steppes. Land area of Pontic steppes is about 400,000 square miles giving a population in that area of around 500,000 nomads and 100,000 city dwellers counting the several small cities in Crimea and along rivers going into Black and Caspian seas.

If the Kipchak confederation extended deeper into western steppes then perhaps a few hundred thousand more but at all times likely less than 1 million in population giving somewhere between 100,000 to 250,000 warriors.

The consensus figure is 1 out of 15 to 1 out of 20 men can be warriors in regular agrarian medieval societies but most scholars agree that ratio is probably a bit different for nomadic cultures so if we use 1 out of 10 or highest possible 1 out of 4 (all men between 15 and 60).

Also there is a bit of confusion on how many tribes and people not directly on the steppes participated in many of the nomadic confederations. There is alot of evidence that some towns and non-steppe dwelling people might have been included in steppe confederations even if not of a shared culture or language due to trade/tithe/marriage alliance reasons.

Thank you that was very helpful

The Cumans & Kipchaks covered a pretty vast area, so getting a total population number (if its possible) would require pooling together numbers from many different places. It would also depend on the time period, since massive events like the Mongol invasions in the 13th century had a big effect on the Cumans-Kipchaks. At that time there seemed to be a lot of them to go around. In 1229 the king of Georgia was able to field an army that included 20,000 Kipchak mercenaries. Koten Khan, the leader of the Cuman-Kipchaks (or at least the western branch) when the Mongols invaded eventually fled to Hungary with 40,000 families. Depending on the average size of Cuman families that could equal as many as 200,000 people. In the east there are also mentions of the Khwarazmians being able to raise large armies of Kipchak mercenaries. In fact that was the backbone of their military.

No one knows if it's Cumans or the Kipchaks who made up the the majority of the population.

" The original meaning of the endonym Cuman is unknown. It is also often unclear whether a particular name refers to the Cumans alone, or to both them and the Kipchaks, as the two tribes often lived side by side.[7] "

"As stated above, it is unknown whether the name Kipchak referred only to the Kipchaks proper, or to the Cumans as well. The two tribes eventually fused, lived together and probably exchanged weaponry, culture and languages; the Cumans encompassed the western half of the confederation, while the Kipchaks and (presumably) the Kangli/Kankalis (a ruling clan of the Pechenegs) encompassed the eastern half.[7]:6 "

I am tempted to say that they were kind of like Turkified Indo-Iranians, initially, who in turn later became somewhat more Slavicised, first during the westward Turkic expansion, and subsequently during the eastward Slavic expansion.

Don't sound very Indo-Iranian or slavicsized.

" According to Ukrainian anthropologists, Kipchaks had racial characteristics of Caucasians and Mongoloids, namely a broad flat face and protruding nose. Researcher E. P. Alekseeva drew attention to the fact that European Kipchak stone images have both Mongoloid and Caucasoid faces "

" The results suggested that the Cumanians, as seen in the excavation at Csengele, were far from genetic homogeneity. Nevertheless, the grave artifacts are typical of the Cumanian steppe culture; and five of the six skeletons that were complete enough for anthropometric analysis appeared Asian rather than European (Horváth 1978, 2001), "
